{{Infobox film | name = Meatballs 4 | image = Meatballs four.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Bob Logan (film director)|Bob Logan]] | producer = [[Donald P. Borchers]]
Ken Halloway
Kris Krengel | writer = [[Bob Logan (film director)|Bob Logan]] | starring = [[Corey Feldman]]
[[Jack Nance]]
[[Sarah Douglas (actress)|Sarah Douglas]]
Bojesse Christopher | music = Steve Hunter | cinematography = Vance Burberry | editing = Peter H. Verity | distributor = [[Moviestore Entertainment]] | released = {{Film date|1992|3|6}} | runtime = 84 min | country = United States | language = English }} '''''Meatballs 4''''' (also known as '''''Meatballs 4: To the Rescue''''') is a 1992 film that was the fourth and final installment to the ''[[Meatballs (film)|Meatballs]]'' series of films. It was shot in its entirety at [[Bass Lake, California]], in the late summer of 1991. Originally conceived as a comedy-drama titled ''Happy Campers'', the project was retooled after production had begun to be part of the ''Meatballs'' series.{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Will|title=Random Roles: Corey Feldman on child actors, his favorite roles, and the Goonies sequel|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/corey-feldman-on-child-actors-his-favorite-roles-a,89648/|accessdate=11 December 2012|newspaper=The A.V. Club|date=10 December 2012}} ==Synopsis== Ricky is the hottest [[waterskiing]] instructor around, and he has just been rehired by his former employer/camp to whip up attendance. However, the camp is in serious financial trouble and the owner of a rival, more popular, camp wants to buy them out. Thus, the two camps engage in a winner-take-all competition that will settle the rivalry once and for all. ==Cast== *[[Corey Feldman]] - Ricky Wade *[[Sarah Douglas (actress)|Sarah Douglas]] - Monica Shavetts *[[Jack Nance]] - Neil Peterson *Steven M. Bradley - Nelson Beyers (Ski Judge) *Bojesses Christophers- Wes Ford *Brad Grunberg- Victor Thigpen (aka Johnny Cocktails) *[[J. Trevor Edmond]]- Howie Duncan *Paige French- Jennifer Lipton *John Mendoza- Dick *[[Bentley Mitchum]]- Kyle Linck *[[Deborah Tucker]]- Kelly Peterson *Frank Walton- Nunzio *[[Cristy Thom]]- Hillary *Brian Christensen- Michael Peltz *Jojo Farkas - Bus Driver *[[Monique Noel]] - Lovelie #1 (cedited as Monique de Lacy) *[[Neriah Davis]] - Nariah ==References== ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090828134130/http://www.meatballsonline.com/ MeatballsOnline] Meatballs Movie Website *{{IMDb title|0104837}} {{The Meatballs Series}} [[Category:1992 films]] [[Category:1990s comedy films]] [[Category:Sequel films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Summer camps in films]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] {{1990s-comedy-film-stub}}

[[Image:Ruthetting.jpg|right|thumb|250px]] The '''musical short''' (a.k.a. '''musical short film''', a.k.a. '''musical featurette''') can be traced back to the earliest days of sound films.
Performers in the [[Lee De Forest]] Phonofilms of 1923-24 included [[Eddie Cantor]], [[George Jessel (actor)|George Jessel]], [[Abbie Mitchell]] ("The Colored Prima Donna") and comic singer-dancer [[Molly Picon]], plus the team of [[Noble Sissel]] and [[Eubie Blake]]. The husband-and-wife vaudeville team of [[Eva Puck]] and [[Sammy White (actor)|Sammy White]] (billed as Puck and White) starred in the Phonofilm ''Opera vs. Jazz'' (1923). [[Max Fleischer]] used the Phonofilm process in 1924 when he introduced his animated ''[[Sound Car-Tunes|Song Car-Tunes]]'' series.<ref name=dark/>
==Vitaphone== The nearly 2,000 [[Vitaphone]] [[short subject]]s produced by [[Warner Bros.]] and its sister studio [[First National Pictures|First National]] from 1926 to 1930 included vaudevillians, opera singers, Broadway stars, dancers, bands and popular vocalists. One and two-reel short musical films were valuable to the movie studios as springboards for new talents. Performers who made their film debuts in short films include [[Joan Blondell]], [[Humphrey Bogart]], [[Burns and Allen]], [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]], [[Judy Garland]] (as Baby Gumm), [[Cary Grant]], [[Bob Hope]], [[Bert Lahr]] and [[Ginger Rogers]].<ref name=dark>[https://books.google.com/books?id=V_C3AmDL314C&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22a+song+in+the+dark%22&lr=&num=100&as_brr=0&sig=gsOABsrZS0quBt7JKQD0_bPY0mw Barrios, Richard. ''A Song in the Dark: The Birth of the Musical Film'', Oxford University Press, 1994.]</ref>
[[Ruth Etting]] sang "My Mother's Eyes" (by Abel Baer and L. Wolfe Gilbert) and "That's Him Now" (by Milton Ager and Jack Yellen) in the [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] Movietone ''Ruth Etting in Favorite Melodies'' (1929), filmed in a single take at the [[Kaufman Astoria Studios|Astoria Studios]] in [[Queens, New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0262190/|title=Ruth Etting|author=|date=|website=IMDb}}</ref> Astoria Studios was built by Paramount in the early days of sound films to provide the company with an audio-capable facility close to the Broadway theater district. Many features and short subjects were filmed there between 1928 and 1933, including the 16-minute ''[[St. Louis Blues (1929 film)|St. Louis Blues]]'' (1929), the only film of [[Bessie Smith]].<ref name=dark/>
==1930s== Orchestra leader [[Phil Spitalny]] made a series of musical shorts beginning with ''Phil Spitalny'' (1929) at [[MGM]], followed by shorts for both Vitaphone and Paramount, including ''Big City Fantasy'' (1929), ''Phil Spitalny and His Musical Queens'' (1934), ''Ladies That Play'' (1934), ''Phil Spitalny and His All Girl Orchestra'' (1935) and ''Sirens of Syncopation'' (1935).
For promotional purposes, major film stars, including [[Gary Cooper]] and [[Clark Gable]], made guest appearances in such musical shorts as MGM's ''Star Night at the Cocoanut Grove'' (1934) and ''[[Starlit Days at the Lido]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0SoIHyxrQM|title=Early three-strip Technicolor in HD -- Henry Busse and His Band -- Hot Lips -- Read Notes!|first=|last=jackusdk|date=9 February 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> (1935), while others featured a single band, such as ''[[Fred Rich|Freddie Rich and His Orchestra]]'' (1938).
[[Richard Barrios]] (author of ''A Song in the Dark: The Birth of the Musical Film'') provided notes for Kino Video's compilation, ''The Best of Big Bands and Swing'': :During the "Dawn of Sound," musical short subjects were the ''[[hors d'œuvre]]'' before the main feature, and an effective means for the studio to test their freshly signed talent in front of the camera. Aggressively pursuing the top singers, songwriters and musicians of Tin Pan Alley, Paramount's roster of contract players was composed of some of the top names in the world of entertainment. Cary Grant makes his film debut as a sailor cruising the Far East in search of whoopee in ''Singapore Sue''. [[Artie Shaw]] presents a master class in the elementals of swingband construction ([[Artie Shaw]]'s ''Class In Swing''). A very young [[Bing Crosby]] croons three ballads in ''Dream House'', a comedy-musical directed by slapstick impresario [[Mack Sennett]]. This collection showcases several top female vocalists, including [[Ethel Merman]] (''Her Future''), [[Ruth Etting]] (''Favorite Melodies'' and [[Lillian Roth]] (''Meet The Boyfriend''). There's also a two-edged homage to that icon of 1930s naughtiness, [[Betty Boop]], with appearances by Betty's prototype, "Boop-a-Doop Girl" [[Helen Kane]] (''A Lesson In Love''), and Betty's actual voice, [[Mae Questel]] (''Musical Doctor'', in which [[Rudy Vallee|Dr. Rudy Vallee]] finds musical deficiencies to be the root of all ills). Perhaps the gem of this collection, however, is ''Office Blues'', in which a pre-[[Fred Astaire|Astaire]] and pre-stardom [[Ginger Rogers]] cavorts with Broadway chorines in an Art Deco extravaganza. With artists like these on the bill it's clear that the short subject -- not the feature -- was often the highlight of the program!<ref>[http://www.kino.com/video/item.php?film_id=640 Barrios, Richard. ''The Best of Big Bands and Swing'', Kino Video.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622141556/http://www.kino.com/video/item.php?film_id=640 |date=2008-06-22 }}</ref>
==1940s== [[Image:Lopezhutton.jpg|right|thumb|350px|Vincent Lopez and Betty Hutton in 1939.]] In the late 1930s and early 1940s, [[Betty Hutton]] made a half-dozen musical shorts before her feature debut in ''[[The Fleet's In]]'' (1942) and then continued to make shorts for the war effort. She was seen in ''Paramount Headliner: Queens of the Air'' (1938), Vitaphone's ''Vincent Lopez and His Orchestra'' (1939), ''Broadway Brevities: One for the Book'' (1939), ''Paramount Headliner: Three Kings and a Queen'' (1939), ''Broadway Brevities: Public Jitterbug Number One'' (1939), ''Paramount Victory Short No. T2-1: [[A Letter from Bataan]]'' (1942), ''Army-Navy Screen Magazine #20: Strictly G.I.'' (1943), Paramount's ''Skirmish on the Home Front'' (1944) and ''Hollywood Victory Caravan'' (1945), produced on the Paramount lot by the Treasury Department for the 1945 Victory Loan Drive. Several of Hutton's musical shorts have been shown on [[Turner Classic Movies]] in recent years.
Modern jazz was added to the mix in such films as the 16-minute ''Artistry in Rhytym'' (1944), with [[Stan Kenton]] and [[Anita O'Day]], later re-edited into another short, ''Cool and Groovy'' (1956), which also featured [[Chico Hamilton]] and [[The Hi-Los]]. In the mid-1940s, [[Louis Jordan]] made short music films, some of which were spliced together into a feature-length musical Western, ''Look-Out Sister'' (1947).
==Television== During the 1950s, musical shorts were revived for telecasting on local stations. Feature films in that decade were usually not edited to fit. Instead, if a feature ended 20 minutes before the hour, footage from musical shorts was used to fill the gap.
[[Snader Telescriptions]] were musical shorts made for television from 1950 to 1954. There were thousands of these three- and four-minute films, covering various genres from jazz and pop to R&B and country. Louis "Duke" Goldstone directed for Louis D. Snader.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macfilms.com/snader.htm|title=Snader Telescriptions|author=|date=|website=macfilms.com}}</ref>
==See also== {{Music video}} *[[Dance in film]] *[[List of big bands]] *[[List of musical films by year]] *[[Music video]] *[[Musical films]] *[[Scopitone]] *[[Soundies]]
==References== {{reflist}}
===Sources=== *Bradley, Edwin R. ''The First Hollywood Sound Shorts, 1926-1931'', McFarland, 2005.
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081122062612/http://www.teachersparadise.com/ency/en/wikipedia/m/mu/music_video.html Teachers Paradise: "Music video"] * [http://www.tvparty.com/vaultvid.html TV's First Music Videos] *[http://www.dailymotion.com/related/2070591/video/x18pbn_venutilang-1929_music Joe Venuti and Eddie Lang, 1929]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
{{Film genres}}

{{original research|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox music genre | name = Neue Volksmusik | native_name = | etymology = [[German language|German]] for "New Folk Music" | other_names = Volxmusik, Tradimix | color = black | bgcolor = #DAA520 | image = | alt = | caption = | stylistic_origins = {{hlist|[[Volksmusik]]|[[pop music|pop]]|[[rock and roll]]|[[swing music|swing]]|[[Country music|country]]|[[folk music|folk]]}} | cultural_origins = 1970's [[Germany]] | instruments = {{hlist|[[Guitar]]|[[electric guitar]]|[[bass guitar]]|[[Drum kit|drums]]|[[keyboard instrument|keyboard]]|[[saxophone]]|[[accordion]]|[[steel guitar]]}} | derivatives = [[Dansband]] | subgenres = | subgenrelist = | fusiongenres = | regional_scenes = Central Europe, Northern Europe, Southeastern Europe | local_scenes = | other_topics = [[Music of Germany]] | footnotes = | current_year = <!-- set to "yes" for automatic link to "<current year> in <genre>" article; see template documentation for more info --> }} '''Neue Volksmusik''' (sometimes also called '''Volxmusik''' or '''Tradimix''', English for "New folk music") describes the [[crossover music|crossover]] mix of traditional German folk music (''[[Volksmusik]]'') with newer genres such as [[jazz]], [[Contemporary folk music|contemporary folk]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], and/or [[Rock music|rock]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.music-news.at/musikgenres/folk/neue-volksmusik/|title=Neue Volksmusik|last=Nestler|first=Lucas|date=18 May 2014|website=Music News|language=German|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.srf.ch/radio-srf-musikwelle/volksmusikfest/neue-volksmusik|title=Neue Volksmusik|last=|first=|date=9 September 2015|website=SRF Swiss Radio|language=German|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 September 2018}}</ref>

[[Viacom 18 Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2017|07|20}} | runtime = 103 minutes | country = [[China]] | language = [[Standard Chinese|Mandarin]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''Our Shining Days''''' ({{lang-zh|c=闪光少女|p=Shǎnguāng Shàonǚ|l=Shining Girl}}) is a 2017 Chinese [[Teen film|coming-of-age]] [[Musical film|musical]] film starring [[Xu Lu]] and [[Peng Yuchang]].{{Cite web|title=《闪光少女》发破壁预告 二次元混搭民乐破次元壁|url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/m/c/2017-07-14/doc-ifyiakwa4091438.shtml|website=Sina|date=July 14, 2017|language=zh}}http://www.scmp.com/culture/film-tv/article/2113788/film-review-our-shining-days-traditional-chinese-music-battles The film has received favorable reviews, particularly for the performance of lead actress Xu Lu and the depiction of [[minority group]]'s struggles of [[Chinese orchestra]] and [[Otaku]].{{Cite web|title=《闪光少女》：徐璐“神经”少女华丽逆袭 |url=http://dy.163.com/v2/article/detail/CPLOQGU50517ACUR.html|website=Netease|date=July 18, 2017|language=zh}}{{Cite web|title=不打架不堕胎，如何拍好青春片？从《闪光少女》看国产青春类型创作新起点|url=http://news.mtime.com/2017/07/17/1571447.html|website=Mtime|date=July 18, 2017|language=zh}}{{Cite web|title=《闪光少女》徐璐演绎失恋是件小事，但成长是件大事|url=http://k.sina.cn/article_6318348016_1789a56f0001003hwj.html|website=Sina|date=February 24, 2018|language=zh}} ==Synopsis== In a fictitious music school, the students of [[Chinese orchestra]] and [[Orchestra|Classical orchestra]] don't get along with each other. They call each other "''tacky''" and "''pretentious''". Chen Jing, a quirky but talented [[yangqin]] student, initially doesn't care about the rivalry, until she falls for the piano prodigy Wang Wen. Annoyed at his ignorance and prejudice toward Chinese instruments, she is determined to prove herself to him by forming her own ensemble, which consists of her best friend who secretly loves her Li You and four ''[[Otaku]]'' girls whom initially only agreed to join because of Chen Jing's promise to buy them expensive [[action figure]]s. They named their [[concert band]] "''2.5 Dimension''", meaning a blend between 2D and 3D worlds, as the Otaku people refer to themselves as living in the second dimension. They perform at an Animation, Comics, and Games convention, and after initial rejection the crowd cheers for them. They perform for Wang Wen but he publicly rejects Chen Jing and traditional Chinese music. Crushed, Chen Jing chooses to disband 2.5 Dimension. The four Otaku students, who have grown to love the band, are angry and refuse Chen Jing's gift of expensive action figures. Chen Jing's mother tells her about how the yangqin is a part of her and that she can't give up playing it without its permission. The head of the school announces plans to cancel the Chinese Orchestra but the original members of 2.5 Dimension are joined by other students to protest. After the head of the school continues to refuse them, they organize a music competition with the Classical Orchestra. An inspector comes to the school and both orchestras play their music. The inspector concludes that they played perfectly together, the groups realize that both have value. ==Casting== *[[Xu Lu]] as Chen Jing, student from the music school's Chinese Music Area who plays the [[Yangqin]] *[[Peng Yuchang]] as Li You, percussionist playing Chinese drums *Liu Yongxi as Xiao Mai, plays the [[Guzheng]] *Li Nuo as Ying Zi, plays the [[Erhu]] *Lu Zhaohua as Beibei, plays the [[Ruan]] *Han Zhongyu as Tata, plays the [[Pipa]] *Luo Mingjie as Wang Wen, plays classical piano *Chen Yusi as Zheng Youen *[[Eason Chan]] as Ministry of Education's official *[[Yan Ni (actress)|Yan Ni]] as Mrs. Chen *Geng Le as Mr. Chen ==Reception== ''Our Shining Days'' garnered generally-positive response, with a rating of 7.4/10 on the Chinese main review site [[Douban]], leading the film to be nominated for ''Best Chinese Film'' at the site's annual list{{Cite web|title=第4届豆瓣电影年度榜单 (2017)的获奖名单 |url=https://movie.douban.com/awards/doubanfilm_annual/4/nominees?k=a|website=Douban|language=zh}} and 6.9/10 on the [[IMDb|Internet Movie Database]]. == Awards and nominations == {| class="wikitable" |rowspan=4|[[Xu Lu]] |{{nom}} |- |[[Tencent]] Star Awards{{Cite web|title=《星光大赏》张艺兴跪地亲吻舞台，徐璐霸气回应“我不是数字小姐”|url=https://www.douban.com/note/647840350/|website=Douban|language=zh}} |Breakthrough Film Actress |{{won}} |- |New Era Film Festival{{Cite web|title=徐璐斩获2017新浪潮女演员奖 闪光少女正当时|url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/s/m/2017-12-15/doc-ifyptkyk4640944.shtml|website=Sina|date=December 15, 2017|language=zh}} 吴京入围最佳导演|date=February 27, 2018|work=ifeng|language=zh}} |Best Actress |{{nom}} |- |Best Film |''Our Shining Days'' |{{nom}} |- |Best Director |rowspan=2|Wang Ran |{{nom}} |- |Best Young Director web|url=http://eladies.sina.com.cn/news/star/2018-03-20/1336/doc-ifyskeuc6757543.shtml|title=第23届华鼎奖提名：《战狼2》、《芳华》双雄逐鹿|date=March 20, 2018|website=Sina|language=zh}} | Best New Director | Wang Ran {{Multiple issues|{{original research|date=November 2017}} {{More references|date=October 2018}}}} [[File:Pepassemblyatschool.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A group of students cheering and clapping at their high school pep assembly.]] A '''pep rally''' or '''pep assembly''' is a gathering of people, typically students of [[middle school]], [[high school]], and [[university|college]] age, before a [[sports]] event. The purpose of such a gathering is to encourage [[school spirit]] and to support members of the [[team]]. It is generally seen as an [[United States|American]] phenomenon.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/daniel-m-cooke/uk-vs-usa-school-pride_b_2696346.html|title=UK vs. USA - School Pride|date=2013-02-19|work=HuffPost UK|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-GB}}</ref>
At a pep rally, cheerleaders lead in boisterous chants and dance moves intended to get the student body excited. Games between competing classes with small prizes may be held. The school's [[School band|band]] often play upbeat music in between demonstrations, and the [[drumline]] may play. The school's choir may sing "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" to the crowd. In the case of a [[homecoming]] game, the Homecoming "court" may be chosen and announced.
This is also a time for the team captains to let the school know how their team are doing this season. Most schools have pep rallies to honor future and past events.
[[College basketball]] teams celebrate the opening of the season with [[Midnight Madness (basketball)|Midnight Madness]], an event similar to a pep rally.
==See also== *[[Pep talk]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{sport-stub}} [[Category:Cheerleading]] [[Category:Sports culture]]

{{Infobox person | bgcolour = | name = Peter Gatien | image = | imagesize = 150px | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|08|08}} | birth_place = [[Cornwall, Ontario]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | spouse = Alessandra Gatien }} '''Peter Gatien''' (born August 8, 1952) is a [[Canadian]] club owner and party promoter. He is best known as the former owner of several prominent [[New York City|New York]] [[nightclub]]s, including Club USA, [[The Limelight]], [[Palladium (club)|Palladium]], and [[Tunnel (New York nightclub)|Tunnel]]. ==Life and career== Gatien was born in [[Cornwall, Ontario]], the third of five brothers.<ref name="canadianbusiness.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.canadianbusiness.com/managing/ceo_interviews/article.jsp?content=20060605_78346_78346 |author=Mlynek, Alex |date=June 2006 |magazine=Canadian Business |title=Live and Learn (CEO Interviews): Peter Gatien |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825153608/http://www.canadianbusiness.com/managing/ceo_interviews/article.jsp?content=20060605_78346_78346 |archivedate=2006-08-25 |df= }}</ref> His first business venture was a [[jeans]] store in his home town, which he opened with a $13,000 settlement after he lost an eye in a hockey accident.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/movies/limelight-doc-tells-outlandish-tale-of-canadians-rise-and-fall-in-nyc/article2176409/ |title=Limelight: Doc tells outlandish tale of Canadian's rise and fall in NYC |date=September 23, 2011 |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |author=Cole, Stephen }}</ref> After that, he turned a former [[country western]] bar into a [[rock music|rock]] club called Aardvark and booked the band [[Rush (band)|Rush]] to perform.<ref name="canadianbusiness.com"/> In 1976, he read about a bankrupt nightclub in [[Florida]] known as Rumbottoms; the space became the first incarnation of [[The Limelight]]. Limelight [[Atlanta]] followed. The longest period of time in which The Limelight remained closed was from 1996 to 1998. It reopened from 1998 until Gatien sold it in 2001, to a real estate developer.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
Gatien produced the film ''[[A Bronx Tale]]'' (1993), starring [[Robert De Niro]],<ref>{{IMDb name|id=0309686|name=Peter Gatien}}</ref> after having produced it as a one-man play starring [[Chazz Palminteri]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.canadianbusiness.com/managing/ceo_interviews/article.jsp?content=20060605_78346_78346&page=2 |work=Canadian Business |title=Peter Gatien |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070312084547/http://www.canadianbusiness.com/managing/ceo_interviews/article.jsp?content=20060605_78346_78346&page=2 |archivedate=2007-03-12 |df= }}</ref>
A 1996 federal investigation attempted but failed to link Gatien to the sales of party drugs,<ref>{{cite news|work=The New York Times|title=Possible Trial Witness Dies|date=January 14, 1998|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/14/nyregion/possible-trial-witness-dies.html }}</ref> especially [[MDMA|ecstasy]], in his clubs, but his acquittal in 1998 left him with huge legal fees.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/22/fashion/peter-gatien-the-fallen-king-of-night-life.html?pagewanted=all |title=Peter Gatien, Club King Without a Club |date=September 21, 2011 |work=[[The New York Times]] |author=Murphy, Tim}}</ref> In addition, he was later arrested on tax evasion charges after a series of club raids; he was acquitted of most of the charges. He pleaded guilty to [[tax evasion]] in 1999, for which he was sentenced to a fine of $1.6 million and a 60-day [[prison]] sentence, along with 5 years' probation. In 2003, he was [[deported]] to his native Canada, under the [[Department of Homeland Security]] [[immigration]] laws which order the removal of any [[alien (law)|alien]] (non-citizen) convicted of a [[felony]].<ref>{{cite news |author= Lianne George |date=Aug 2012 |url= http://nymag.com/nightlife/features/17066/ |title= Bright Lights, Medium-Size City |work= New York Magazine}}</ref> However, because he is part [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Canadian]], Gatien has since been able to visit the United States again.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/rush_molloy/2007/08/14/2007-08-14_gatien_returns_to_us_on_indian_path.html |accessdate=January 22, 2008 |title=Gatien returns to U.S. on Indian path |work=[[New York Daily News]] |date=August 14, 2007 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080122045634/http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/rush_molloy/2007/08/14/2007-08-14_gatien_returns_to_us_on_indian_path.html |archivedate=January 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Gatien relocated to [[Toronto]], where he opened a {{convert|55,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} entertainment venue, Circa.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fabmagazine.com/features/292/Second_Coming.html |title=Second coming for Toronto's club scene|work=Fab Magazine}}</ref> By 2009, he was no longer involved with Circa and has been out of the nightclub business since that time. Circa was forced into bankruptcy and closed its doors in March 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://torontojungle.com/forum/showthread.php/69512-The-rise-and-fall-of-Circa-nightclub |title=The Downfall of Circa Night Club |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025062520/http://torontojungle.com/forum/showthread.php/69512-The-rise-and-fall-of-Circa-nightclub |archivedate=2012-10-25 |df= }}</ref>
==In popular culture== ===Books=== *Gatien and the histories of his clubs are discussed at length in the book ''The Last Party: Studio 54, Disco, and the Culture of the Night'', by [[Anthony Haden-Guest]]. Haden-Guest's book chronicles the history of New York nightlife and all the significant people and events that impacted its evolution from [[Studio 54]] through to the days of Club USA, The Limelight, Palladium, and Tunnel. *Gatien is a prominent character in two books about [[scandals]] involving former club promoter [[Michael Alig]], including: ** ''[[Disco Bloodbath]]: A Fabulous but True Tale of Murder in Clubland'' (1999) by [[James St. James]] **''Clubland Confidential: The Fabulous Rise and Murderous Fall of Club Culture'' (2003) by Frank Owen <ref>{{cite book|title=Clubland Confidential |author=Owen, Frank|date=2003|isbn=9780091885786|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/739169.Clubland_Confidential?from_search=true}}</ref>
===Films=== *St. James' book, ''Disco Bloodbath'', was later made into two films: **''[[Party Monster: The Shockumentary]]'' (1998), a documentary ** ''[[Party Monster (2003 film)|Party Monster]]'' (2003), a feature film starring [[Macaulay Culkin]] as Michael Alig, and [[Seth Green]] as James St. James, that chronicles the events leading up to the murder of [[Angel Melendez]], committed by [[Michael Alig]] and his roommate, Robert D. "Freeze" Riggs. Gatien is played by [[Dylan McDermott]].
*Gatien's daughter, Jen Gatien, produced the documentary ''[[Limelight (2011 documentary)|Limelight]]'' (2011), about New York City night life in the 1990s, and the rise and fall of her father's club empire.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bose, Chew|first=Durga|title=Jen Gatien Dives Into the Limelight (Again)|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/blogs/film/2011-03-14/jen-gatien-limelight/|magazine=Interview Magazine|date=March 14, 2011|accessdate=20 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110517204331/http://www.interviewmagazine.com/blogs/film/2011-03-14/jen-gatien-limelight/|archivedate=17 May 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Toys=== *In 2007, Gatien was made into a Dunny, a type of vinyl designer toy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kidrobot.com/content.cfm?section=dunny |website=Kidrobot |title=Yearly editions gallery|accessdate= 16 February 2009}}</ref>
===Music=== *Gatien is mentioned in the song, "The Fun Lovin' Criminal" by [[The Fun Lovin' Criminals]]: "I am always optimistic about human relations, I got more friends than my man Peter Gatien" *He is also mentioned in the song, "Foundation" by [[Jay-Z]], who raps: "Me and my operation, running New York nightscene, with one eye closed, like Peter Gatien" *He is also mentioned in the song, "Dynasty" by [[The Diplomats]]: "Meet Jimmy Iovine, give me my cream Shapiro, Peter Gatien, relation Spot a club in L.A just to touch it up"
==References== {{Reflist}}
==See also== *[[Club Kids]]

{{italic title}} '''''Pikker''''' was an [[Estonia]]n magazine of satire and humor published between 1943 and 1991.
During 1943–1944 ''Pikker'' existed as satire and humor supplement to the Soviet Estonian newapaper ''[[Rahva Hääl]]'' and printed in [[Moscow]] and [[Leningrad]].<ref>[http://erb.nlib.ee/?kid=11466911 "Pikker (Moskva, Leningrad"], ''Eesti rahvusbibliograafia''</ref>
In 1945 its editorial office was moved to [[Tallinn]], [[Estonian SSR]].<ref>[http://erb.nlib.ee/?kid=10727590 "Pikker (Tallinn)"], ''Eesti rahvusbibliograafia''</ref>
In 1987, on [[April Fools' Day]] the magazine issued a humor award, [[Meie Mats]].

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=August 2018}} {{underlinked|date=July 2018}} }}
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}}
{{short description|Israeli video game series}} {{Infobox video game series | image = Piposh_game.jpg | caption = Cover image of the first game |genre=Point-and-click adventure, Comedy|developer=Guillotine|publisher=Hed Artzi Multimedia| platform of origin=Windows | first release version=1999 | latest release version=2004 }}
'''''Piposh''''' ({{lang-he|'''פיפוש'''}}) is an [[Israel|Israeli]] media franchise that commenced with a series of comedic [[Point and click|point-and-click]] [[Adventure game|adventure video games]] developed by Guillotine and published by [[Hed Arzi Multimedia]] for Windows. Based around the eponymous actor-turned-detective who embarks on several adventures solving murders, the titles include ''Piposh'', ''Piposh 2'', ''Halom SheItgashem'' (spinoff), and ''Piposh 3D: HaMahapecha''. An English version of ''Piposh'' entitled ''Piposh: Hollywood'' was released in either 2002 or 2004. The series, which began in 1999, was created at a time when the Israeli video gaming industry was at its peak, particularly in terms of adventure gaming, and served as an notable example of a work targeted specifically at the young local market, with aspects such as inside jokes relating to Israeli culture. The games became very popular, although never becoming financially successful, and its developers struggled to live off the proceeds.
''Piposh'' evolved into a franchise, with a television series, a comic book, and an album being created. The series continues to have a dedicated fanbase, and conventions known as 'Piposh Congresses' have been regularly held as a way for fans to celebrate the games together. While the titles have often been criticised for their amateurish visual style and clunky game mechanics, they are looked at fondly by critics who see ''Piposh'' as a source of Israeli pride and a key milestone in the advancement of the local industry throughout the 21st century.
== Plot and gameplay ==
The series consists of point and click adventures, requiring players to interact with an inventory and with characters in order to complete puzzles and advance the story. The main character is intended to be a caricature of the arrogant Israeli, with a worldview that "the whole world is an idiot – and that talk can not be done quietly, only with shouting".<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-2458275,00.html|title=Cheerful Piposh campaigns|last=Birab|first=Yuval|date=February 26, 2003|website=Ynet|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The plot of ''Piposh'' follows the quirky adventures of its main character, flawed actor Hezi Piposh, as he boards the wrong boat and encounters various hijinks including being caught up in a murder. He can interrogate characters, break into their rooms, and accuse them of murder.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE2.asp|title=Piposh 1 (1999)|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> In ''Piposh 2,'' Piposh finds himself trapped on an island populated by dwarves, who help him assemble an aviation device to escape.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE3.asp|title=Piposh 2 (2000)|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> ''Halom SheItgashem'' sees eight strange acquaintances be invited to the castle of an eccentric man.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE4.asp|title=Halom SheItgashem|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> ''Piposh 3D'' revolves around a political revolution that ensues because the entire country decides to become vegetarian, replacing meat with tofu.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE5.asp|title=Piposh 3D: HaMahapecha (2003)|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
==History==
=== Conception and ''In the Interest of Ratings'' === After Renen Glutzman left the Israeli army and while his brother Roy was still a member, they set up a small graphics business in [[Pardes Hanna-Karkur|Pardes Hanna]] (פרדס חנה), where they did routine projects for commission.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.928084|title=Piposh hangs the keyboard|last=Smooha|first=Shahar|date=January 12, 2003|work=Haaretz|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> In 1997, one of their projects reached the desk of the CEO of video game distributor Hed Artzi Multimedia (הד ארצי מולטימדיה), the multimedia arm of Israeli record label [[Hed Arzi Music]], who liked the illustration style of the duo and suggested they create a Hebrew-language computer game. He gave them [[Israeli new shekel|NIS]] 10,000 in return for 50% of the future profits from the sales.<ref name=":4" />
Despite having no experience in the video gaming industry, the team went to work and after nine months of development, released ''[[In the Interest of Ratings]] (בתככי הרייטינג)'', a title which focused on the incompetent detective Elimelech Egoz (voiced by Moshe Ferster), who goes on holiday at the fictional Nofei Hadera Hotel only to be greeted by a bizarre murder case.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://timeout.co.il/%D7%9E%D7%99%D7%95%D7%97%D7%93%D7%99%D7%9D/%D7%92%D7%99%D7%91%D7%95%D7%A8-%D7%A0%D7%A2%D7%95%D7%A8%D7%99/%D7%9E%D7%A9%D7%97%D7%A7-%D7%94%D7%97%D7%99%D7%99%D7%9D-%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F-%D7%A2%D7%9D-%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A6%D7%A8%D7%99-%D7%A4%D7%99%D7%A4%D7%95%D7%A9-%D7%95-%D7%91%D7%AA%D7%9B%D7%9B|title=The Game of Life: An Interview with the Creators of "Piposh" and "The Ratings Games"|last=Blau|first=Dune|date=July 10, 2014|work=TimeOut|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he-IL}}</ref> The game contained intertextuality, inside jokes, irony, and cynicism.<ref name=":1" /> ''In the Interest of Ratings'' received negative reviews in the press, including in ''Internet Captain (קפטן האינטרנט''), the technology/multimedia branch of the leading Israeli newspaper ''[[Haaretz]]''; however it received positive reviews in youth-oriented newspapers. Ultimately the game was relatively popular, though it was not financially successful.<ref name=":4" /> But it led the duo to decide to try to develop a second video game, which would become ''Piposh''<ref name=":4" />, under their new development company Guillotine (גיליוטין).
{{Timeline of release years |1999a=''Piposh'' game (פיפוש) |1999b=''Piposh'' weekly comic strip |1999c=''Piposh and Other Vegetables'' comic book (פיפוש ושאר ירקות) |1999d= ''Piposh Congresses'' fan conventions (הקונגרס הפיפושי) |2000=''Piposh 2'' game (פיפוש 2) |2001a=''Halom SheItgashem'' game (חלום שהתגשם, spin-off) |2001b= ''Batheshet Moav'' TV show (בטשת מואב, spin-off) |2002=''Piposh Hollywood'' game (English remake of ''Piposh'') |2003=''Piposh 3D: HaMahapecha'' game (פיפוש 3די- המהפכה) |2004= ''At the Piposh Tavern'' (album) |2008=''Piposh 2.5 and the Stolen Vase'' game (fan-made; cancelled) |title=Games released timeline}}
=== ''Piposh'' === The Gluzman brothers wrote the text and the code, drew the backgrounds and characters, and created the animations; in addition they convinced actors Shai Avivi, Amos Shuv, Anat Magen, Ilan Peled, Dudu Zar, Meni Pe'er, and Ilan Ganani (as Piposh) to voice characters voluntarily.<ref name=":4" /> The game was developed by four people in their garage, at a time when the computer gaming industry in Israel was considered non-existent.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3540692,00.html|title=In honor of Independence Day: "Piposh" free download|last=Birab|first=Yuval|date=August 5, 2008|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Glutzman recalls that Guillotine was not particularly well managed, lacked business planning and didn't have a financial focus, and instead consisted of a naive team who wanted to simply make something "fun and cool".<ref name=":0" /> ''[[Ynet]]'' asserts the duo was irrational for choosing set up a development company for Israeli games that only appealed to the local market.<ref name=":6" /> Ronen would later describe the contemporary Israeli video gaming industry as an imaginary thing to pursue, for four young developers working from their garage.<ref name=":0" /> During development, Renen used the program ''[[Macromedia Director|Macromedia Director 4]]'', and he created each game screens from scratch.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://whileiwasworking.blogspot.com/2008/05/piposh.html|title=Piposh / פיפוש|last=Gafni|first=Etay|date=May 9, 2008|website=WHILE I WAS WORKING...|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> At the time of the game's release, Renen published his phone number to allow stuck players to phone in for help.<ref name=":1" />
After a year and a half of development, ''Piposh'' was released; it became a hit among teenagers and sold either 6000 copies<ref name=":4" /> or over 7000 copies<ref name="piposh.co.il">{{cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il|title=Guillotine Hebrew home page|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.articles.co.il/article/27357/%D7%A4%D7%99%D7%AA%D7%95%D7%97%20%D7%9E%D7%A9%D7%97%D7%A7%D7%99%20%D7%9E%D7%97%D7%A9%D7%91%20%D7%91%D7%90%D7%A8%D7%A5|title=Development of computer games in Israel|last=Gur|first=Adiel|date=October 11, 2008|work=M'amrim (Articles)|access-date=June 27, 2018|language=he}}</ref> over a period of one year in retail sales.<ref name="piposh.co.il" /> They achieved this without reducing the original selling price.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/english.htm|title=Piposh English home page|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> ''Haaretz'' asserts that many thousands more probably illegally pirated it.<ref name=":4" /> The game reached 5th place on the sales charts, and for a few weeks was competitive with the best-selling games from abroad.<ref name=":5" /> Some of Piposh’s royalties were donated to the animal rights and welfare organizations.<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE15.asp|title=About the creators|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> The game originally had text and voicework in Hebrew, though a few years later it was made available in both English and Russian<ref name="piposh.co.il" />, and due to its success Guillotine was able to distribute the games to the United States and Russia.<ref name="auto" /><ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=October 2014|title=Gaming|url=https://issuu.com/asat-site/docs/_______________________|journal=Factor: Technion Student Newsletter|volume=62|pages=5|via=}}</ref> Due to the title's low minimum requirements, it was able to be played on computers with weaker processing power.<ref name=":5" /> The game was deemed an adventure gaming success aimed primarily at the local market, having been developed independently, almost underground.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3878156,00.html|title=From the star to the bamba: The Israelis who make games|last=Brenner|first=Itai|date=April 19, 2010|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> While not officially a Piposh title, ''In the Interest of Ratings'' has a link to the series; within ''Piposh'', the main character – a flawed actor – claims to have played Egoz in the previous game.<ref>{{Cite web|url=|title=Piposh|last=|first=|date=1999|website=Guillotine|publisher=Hed Arzi Multimedia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
=== Rest of the series === Roy left the series during production of the second game, believing that in addition to piracy, the distribution networks weren't as efficient at bringing video games to stores as other products like Israeli music.<ref name=":4" /> According to Renen, his brother did not have prowess in the business and marketing side to succeed in the industry.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514015759/http://news.vgames.co.il/article.aspx?SectionID=2119|title=Special for Yom HaAtzma'ut: Greetings to Piposh|last=Beirav|first=Yuval|date=August 5, 2008|website=Vgames|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> After leaving, Roy moved away from sensationalist nature of the entertainment and gaming industry, and instead focused in personal creative projects.<ref name=":4" /><ref name="auto2"/> On his own Renen began to suffer financially, which would continue for years while making the Piposh games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.makorrishon.co.il/nrg/online/16/ART/968/091.html|title=Game theory|last=Globerman|first=Dror|date=August 8, 2005|website=Maariv|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> By 2003 he was living on 30 shekels a day.<ref name=":6" /> He would later explain that at the time, to be a video game developer in Israel, one was expected not to make money.<ref name=":0" /> While the first game took 1.5 years to make, the team spent a year making Piposh 2, and a year making ''Halom SheItgashem''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/NK/NK3.htm|title=An interview with Renan and Roi Gluzman about Nahum Heiman and Ya'akov Katz...|last=Gluzman|first=Renan and Roi|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> Each time the developers made a game, they did it independently and without external funding.<ref name=":6" /> Once a title neared completion, Guillotine spoke to their distribution company to print discs and send them to stores.<ref name=":6" /> However, as the distribution company was very large they didn't have time to invest into a small local game like ''Piposh'' so the games ended up being sent out two weeks later than intended, once the advertising and buzz had died down.<ref name=":6" /> For each title, Renan produced advertising materials such as posters, business cards and funny stickers.<ref name=":6" />
''Piposh 3D'' was the series' first foray into 3D graphics, after using traditional animation for the previous games; this title was directed by Roy Lazarowitz.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/DETAILS.htm|title=Disclosure and incriminating information about Gilliotin|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> By this point the developers had grown tired of their distributor and sought to use Indogram, which represented fewer games and could therefore invest more time into each.<ref name=":6" /> It was developed using the A5 engine, which Guillotine had purchase specifically for this title.<ref name=":15" /> 2004 saw the English release of ''Piposh'' entitled ''Piposh Holywood'', which was to be published by The Phantom after [[Phantom Entertainment]] bought the distribution rights electronically. ''Ynet'' noted that if successful, it would have been a notable achievement for the industry, seeing the first Israeli video game released on console, but noting the unclear outcome of this venture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-2858473,00.html|title=Piposh will ride The Phantom|last=Moore|first=Noam|date=January 13, 2004|website=Ynet|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Guillotine had aimed to translate their first Piposh game to break it into the international market, however the text and dubbing translations became an astronomical task due to the original game having a badly-constructed programming interface.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE7.asp|title=Piposh Hollywood|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> The foreign adaption of the first game is known worldwide by its English title.<ref name=":7" /> The games were not intended to meet the technological standards of the global industry, particularly in terms of graphics.<ref name=":4" /> They were not targeted to a worldwide audience, instead appealing to Israeli teenagers who were not necessarily gamers, but who wanted immature content with cultural references they would understand.<ref name=":4" /> ''Haaretz'' contends that despite the development team tapping into the minds of local youth, the rampant pirate copying phenomenon prevented them from making a living of their games.<ref name=":4" />
''Piposh'' saw numerous opportunities for franchise expansion over its history. The team gave up a NIS 20,000 offer by [[Burgeranch|Burger Ranch]] to distribute the games because they were vegetarians.<ref name=":02">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3540692,00.html|title=In honor of Independence Day: "Piposh" free download|last=Birab|first=Yuval|date=August 5, 2008|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Soon after the release of Piposh, the duo started creating a weekly comic section in the local youth newspapers Rosh 1 and Maariv LeYanar<ref name="auto22">{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE15.asp|title=About the creators|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref>, and also created a comic book which was published by Hed Artzi<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080615031146/http://piposh.vgames.co.il:80/|title=Website to download Piposh games|last=|first=|date=June 15, 2008|website=Piposh.vgames.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref>, released under the title "Piposh and Other Vegetables" (פיפוש ושאר ירקות)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/YEREK.htm|title=Piposh and other vegetables|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="auto3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/DETAILS.htm|title=Disclosure and incriminating information about Gilliotin|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.808274|title=Comics|last=|first=|date=July 9, 2002|work=Haaretz|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref>, which could be purchased from the official Guillotine site.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE10.asp|title=Beetle and other vegetables|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> They also lectured to youth at an animation and comics festival at the Tel Aviv Cinematheque.<ref name="auto22" /> In 2000, the developers thought of porting Piposh to mobile phones, having already set up documents such as an instillation guide; however this never came to fruition.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10214200557825856&set=g.13843284369&type=1&theater&ifg=1|title=Installation document for mobile port of Piposh|last=|first=|date=2000|website=Guillotine|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> A spin-off television series named Batheshet Moav (בטשת מואב) – ten episodes in length and about five minutes per episode – first aired on the Beep channel in either 2001<ref name=":72">{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/BATESHET.htm|title=Batheshet Moav|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ishim.co.il/m.php?s=%D7%91%D7%98%D7%A9%D7%AA+%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%90%D7%91|title=Batheshet Moav|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Ishim.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref name="auto22" /> or February 5, 2002.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10211859423455801&set=p.10211859423455801&type=3&theater&ifg=1|title=Batheshet Moav listing|last=|first=|date=2002|website=Beep|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10211859422335773&set=g.13843284369&type=1&theater&ifg=1|title=Batheshet Moav listing|last=|first=|date=2002|website=Beep|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> A previous concept for the show – where viewers could interact by choosing which of two outcomes they wanted to watch – was offered to Fox Kids.<ref name=":72" /> While Fox wanted to sign a contract, Guillotine refused as they did not want to give up the rights and the artistic freedom, for instance they would be censored from using the swear word קיבינימט and from mentioning that Piposh's father drowned in the [[Yarkon River]].<ref name=":02" /> An album featuring music, interviews, and other content entitled ''At the Piposh Tavern'' was released by Guillotine and the Tag Group in 2004.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.piposh.co.il/n_store-tav_playlist.htm|title=At the Piposh Tavern|last=|first=|date=April 11, 2004|website=Piposh.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> A fourth game (excluding the spinoff) was to be released but this was eventually cancelled.<ref name="auto3" /> Running until at least 2004, 'Piposh Congresses' have been held as national meeting for all the fans of Piposh and Guillotine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-2980392,00.html|title=The Ninth Congress|last=Zarbiv|first=Danny|date=September 22, 2004|website=Ynet|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The developers sold an "I'm Pipposi Proud" game package, which included 5 game discs including the first three titles, plus a demo of Piposh 3D and a disc with rare files and documents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE11.asp|title=, אני פיפושי גאה|website=www.2all.co.il|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
=== Aftermath === The last title developed by Guillotine was the network-strategy nonsense game Vajimon, which saw players fight against each other over the internet using a variety of vegetables.<ref name=":4" /> Around 2003-4, the company's operations were terminated and its managers retired.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216010237/www.piposh2ah.2us.co.il/|title=Welcome to the new site of Search 2.5|last=|first=|date=December 16, 2008|website=Sellotape|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Ronen left the industry soon after due to the financial and mental burden the series had given him<ref name=":6" />, and became a yacht skipper.<ref name=":4" /> He earned money as a writer of games for interactive TV and cell phone in a leading high tech company.<ref name="auto2"/> In 2005, the brothers lectured for a Gameology course at Beit Berl College as part of the first Israeli curriculum course for video game development.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/captain/games/1.1511799|title=For the first time in Israel, a path for game developers|last=Yaron|first=Oded|date=March 21, 2005|work=Haaretz|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> The program was started by Dr. Diana Silverman Keller who discovered while writing her thesis that there was no formal education in the field of game creation in the country. She noted that "Despite the success of Israeli high-tech, the Israelis do not excel at developing games".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/gallery/1.1075310|title=Bush is out of the game|last=Ofek|first=Kobi|date=2006|work=Haaretz|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Keller contacted Renen, who at the time was known as the "spiritual father of the Israeli gaming community", and he soon became a central figure in the program.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.1029708|title=An academic path will train the future generation of computer game creators|last=Gotliv|first=Tzvika|date=July 22, 2005|work=Haaretz|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref>
On May 7, 2008, on Israel's 60th Independence Day, all Guillotine games were re-released for free download from the Internet. Renen Gluzman noted that the games were unplayable unless the gamer had a Windows 95 computer, and commented "I felt that I had to do this, in order to save the game from falling into the abyss".<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> By this time, it was impossible to get the games anymore, and there were no orderly backups.<ref name=":0" /> He noted it was strange to revisit these games after having not touched them since the series ended in 2003.<ref name=":0" /> Tal Dinovich, a fan of the series who had volunteered for years on the site and answered phone called from stuck players, helped locate all the game files and create updated versions that would work on Windows XP.<ref name=":0" /> While Renen has since moved on from the series, he did create a Facebook group for the fans who had grown up with the series and wanted to reminisce.<ref name=":2" /> According to [[Calcalist]], the series released 7 games, 4 of which are available for free download.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.calcalist.co.il/internet/articles/0,7340,L-3287147,00.html|title=Play Free: 24 full games|last=Yogev|first=Audi|date=May 27, 2009|work=Calcalist|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> As part of the campaign, Ronen aimed to print special nostalgic shirts, as this was a common fan request.<ref name=":0" />
In December 2008, a group of Piposh fans, believing that it had died prematurely, started a campaign to create a new chapter of the series and started looking for volunteers. The game, to be developed through their company Sellotape (סלוטייפ) was entitled ''Piposh 2.5 and the Stolen Vase''.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://archive.is/6Epca#selection-2717.143-2717.171|title=Piposh 2.5?|last=David|first=Noa|date=December 12, 2008|website=Nana 10|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The official website of the project wrote that while the developers were unable to reach the quality level of the official games, they hoped to emulate it as much as possible.<ref name=":10" /> Their aim was to "remember, save, and enjoy" the Piposh series.<ref name=":9" /> The plot, taking place immediately after Piposh 2, sawthe protagonist try to find the magic 'vase of life' that can be used by his to resurrect characters to died in the prequel.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=http://www.2all.co.il/web/sites/hezipiposh/PAGE16.asp|title=Piposh 2 and a half – the stolen vase|last=|first=|date=2018|website=www.2all.co.il|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The producer/director was Ben Werchizer, the artist/designer was Daniel Avdo, the music and dubbing producer was Itay Jeroffi, and the writer was Shahar Kraus;<ref name=":9" /> they were looking for professional programmers in Director or Flash<ref name=":9" /> as well as voice talent.<ref name=":10" /> Their site contained a "build your own character" minigame from the series as a flash game, and a forum dedicated to the resurrection of Piposh.<ref name=":10" /> The project was discontinued around 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.xplace.com/il/en/job/12362|title=We need a programmer to develop a sequel to the Israeli series "Piposh" in the Piposh style on Macromedia Direcor|last=|first=|date=June 7, 2010|website=Xplace|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref>
Video game archivist and founder of the ''Movement for Preservation of Games in Israel'' Raphael Ben-Ari got in touch with the series' creators and detailed the story behind its development process and in a documentary film.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ShimurIsrael/posts/1398126163819442|title=Piposh|last=Ben-Ari|first=Raphael|date=February 25, 2016|website=Movement for Preservation of Games in Israel|publisher=Facebook|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> The documentary was uploaded to YouTube on Ben-Ari's ''Oldschool'' account.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=28jxusMNkhw|title=The most fun game in Hebrew (and how it was developed)|last=Ben-Ari|first=Raphael|date=Feb 25, 2016|website=Oldschool|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Ben-Ari believes the work boosted the Piposh community in Israel and introduced the series to many new people.<ref name=":3" />
== State of Israeli industry at the time == The Israeli video gaming industry was at its peak in the 1990s, with several companies creating games, developing engines, and trying to become successful both at home and abroad. One example is [[:he:מחשבת (חברה)|Machshevet]] (מחשבת), which began as an importer and translator of games to the Israeli market. In the mid-1990s, the company would create children's video games based on popular legends and fairytales.called 'CD Pedoph' (סי.די פדוף"). Created during the golden age of the point and click adventure games, two of Machshevet's popular titles are: ''[[:he:שליט המימדים|Dimension Commander: The Adventures of Wonderland]]'' (שליט המימדים: מסע ההרפתקאות המופלא) (1996) and [[Armed & Delirious|''Armed & Delirious'']] (1997).<ref name=":16" /> Compedia (קומפדיה), while primarily a technologies, platforms and systems developer, also created educational computer games which were distributed to over 40 countries, including the ''Advanced Thinking Skills'' series (1992–93), the ''Timmy'' series (1994–95), the ''Gordy'' series (סדרת גורדי), the ''Itamar'' series (סדרת איתמר), ''Gordy in the Movie Adventure'' (גורדי בהרפתקה מהסרטים), ''In Search of the Lost Words'' (בעקבות המילים האבודות 1996/1998), and ''Julia: Back to the Sweet 60's'' (2001). Other notable Israeli video games of the time include: ''[[Xonix]]'' (1984), ''Intifada'' (אינתיפאדה 1989), and [[:he:סוחר הים (משחק מחשב)|''The Sea Dealer'']] (סוחר הים 1989), ''Bonus'' (בונוס), ''Avish'' (אביש 1993), ''Duvalle'' (דובל'ה 1993-1997), [[Jane's IAF: Israeli Air Force|''Jane's IAF: Israeli Air Force'']] (1998), and ''You Think You're Smart'' (אתה חושב שאתה חכם 1998-2001).<ref name=":16" /> Throughout the 1990s, Israeli developers also created various "silly little games...to promote children's food products" such as Vered Hagalil and Bamba.<ref name=":8" />
Factor believed that while the 80s and 90s saw the serious development of games within Israel, with the country being at the peak of its video gaming industry, it was still defined by a level of inferiority on the world stage, which had only started to improve in the early 2010s with social and casual gaming apps.<ref name=":12" /> Makorrishon wrote that Piposh was created at a time when it was generally accepted that to make good games one had to work abroad in a large company.<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=https://www.makorrishon.co.il/nrg/online/10/ART/757/903.html|title=The Israeli Who Will Fly Harry Potter|last=Rivlin|first=Jesse|date=July 20, 2004|website=Makorrishon|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> Video game developer Adiel Gur thinks that Guillotine's did not have many contemporaries because of a lack of interest from high-tech companies to make games, a belief from producers that the sector is unprofitable, a lack of resources and tools for developers to make professional games, and the difficulty in amassing a team of workers from different fields (graphic artists, programmers, scriptwriters etc.).<ref name="auto1" /> Ynet wrote that considering the number of Israelis studying computer science and the reputation of the country as a hub for high-tech entrepreneurs, it was surprising "how much an Israeli gaming industry does not exist", describing it as a "local vacuum".<ref name=":8" /> Roy explained that in his opinion: "People who have the ability to develop computer games prefer to develop navigation applications and worm software that will sabotage the reactor in Iran".<ref name=":1" /> In one case, the developers of Ballerium (2001) had to first present a comprehensive business plan in order to lure potential investors.<ref name=":8" />
In 2001, Ynet wrote that it was difficult to name Israeli games that were not children's edutainment, and though able to recall some popular titles, with exception to ''Jane's IAF: Israeli Air Force'' called them "negligible in terms of scope and technicality" and non-competitive in the global market.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-709312,00.html|title=Game Made in Israel|last=Yogev|first=Udi|date=May 2, 2001|website=Ynet|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In 2008, the site asserted that until recently, apart from children's edutainment developer [[:he:קומפדיה|Compedia]] and the Piposh series, there was no video gaming industry in Israel,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3527394,00.html|title=Patriotic games|last=Lilien|first=Niv|date=April 4, 2008|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> though expressed hope that the action game ''Rising Eagle'' would change that.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3503959,00.html|title=Rising Eagle review: An Israeli Game|last=Roitblatt|first=Avishay|date=February 7, 2008|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Meanwhile, in 2008 Eser wrote: "It's not that I think there is no future for the Israeli computer games industry, and that there is no need to nurture it".<ref name=":15" />
== Critical reception == The games became a cult hit in Israel, known for their unique humor, original characters and a satirical look at Israeli society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://10tv.nana10.co.il/Article/?ArticleID=554015|title=Free Piposh|last=Jnana|first=|date=May 13, 2008|website=Eser|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Ronen is notable for being one of a few Israelis who have managed to develop a computer game within the country and distribute it in Israel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3164686,00.html|title=Israel's first school for game developers was launched|last=Azar|first=Lihi|date=November 6, 2005|website=Ynet|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> According to ''Timeout'', the games are hilarious and brave.<ref name=":1" /> ''Eser'' felt that Piposh was a "semi-decent adventure game".<ref name=":15" /> Bikorate felt the title had a "fascinating plot and humor ahead of its time".<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sites.google.com/site/bikorate/mishakim|title=Video Games|last=|first=|date=2018|website=Bikorate|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> The student newsletter Factor thought the game was "more funny, more ingenious, and generally more universal" than ''In the Interest of Ratings'' had been a year earlier, and felt the two games were "exemplary examples of Israeli creativity".<ref name=":12" /> In 2001, ''Ynet'' asserted that the few games of Israeli origin such as Piposh were "quite negligible in terms of scope and technicality", and were "not close to being competitive in the global market"<ref name=":8" />, however in 2003 the site saw the series as a source of Israeli pride.<ref name=":6" /> The site would later come to feel that the series offered some of the most "bizarre, funny and hallucinatory quests" to come out of gaming, noting that the first title is widely regarded as a cult game, and that many peculiar moments from the series are etched into the minds of players.<ref name=":16">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4368049,00.html|title=Blue and white gaming: From Xonix to Blue Star|last=Frost|first=Tal|date=April 16, 2013|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Bikorate thought Piposh 2 surprised with its "witty and satirical jokes about Israeli society".<ref name=":11" />
The Hebrew site ''Eser,'' despite having sympathy for Israeli game developers, who are "forced to work in almost impossible conditions" when compared to their American and European colleagues, gave Piposh 3D a scathing review; while calling its premise amusing, and noting that the patient ''Piposh'' fanbase would overlook its inferior graphics the site felt the game was very bad, likening it to a "singer singing without makeup".<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=https://www.10.tv/online/57155|title=Piposh: The Revolution|last=Zeerman|first=Idan|date=June 23, 2008|website=Eser|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://10tv.nana10.co.il/Article/?ArticleID=561139|title=Piposh: The Revolution|last=Zeerman|first=Idan|date=February 7, 2008|website=Eser|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ''Ynet'' criticised 3D's graphics and interface, though noted its humour and charm might make up for the experience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-2615517,00.html|title=Piposh 3D: A matter of taste|last=Reshef|first=Noam|date=May 3, 2011|work=Ynet|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Ben-Ari feels a sense of patriotism toward the game as a piece of video gaming software that is proudly and unabashedly Israeli.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://oldschool.org.il/videos/%D7%A4%D7%99%D7%A4%D7%95%D7%A9-%D7%A1%D7%99%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A8-%D7%95%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F-%D7%A2%D7%9D-%D7%94%D7%9E%D7%A4%D7%AA%D7%97%D7%99%D7%9D/|title=Search: Coverage and interview with developers|last=Ben-Avi|first=Raphael|date=February 25, 2016|website=Oldschool|language=he-IL|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> ''Sport5'' listed the game in their article ''There is honor: the greatest Israeli computer games ever'', rating it 10/10 and praising its unique crazy and sharp sense of creativity and humour, as well as for sparking one of the "most cohesive computer game communities ever in the country".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sport5.co.il/articles.aspx?FolderID=7901&docID=278533&lang=HE|title=There is honor: the greatest Israeli computer games ever|last=Ben-Yishai|first=Matan|date=April 19, 2018|website=Sport5.co.il|language=HE|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> ''Haaretz'' deemed it ultimately a failed initiative to establish the Israeli video gaming industry, despite its significance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/1.1105033|title=Looking for the Israeli Pacman|last=Grimelnad|first=Gia|date=March 14, 2006|work=Haaretz|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he}}</ref> Factor thought the series attempt to enter the 3D market was an "utter failure".<ref name=":12" /> Even though Walla thought Piposh 3D was a bad game, it thought the game looked like a masterpiece in comparison with ''Dangerous Vaults'', a Lara Croft parody that forces players to have sex with animals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tech.walla.co.il/item/782874|title=Sex with Animals|last=Moshe|first=Nimrod Ben|date=September 20, 2005|work=Walla|access-date=May 26, 2018|language=he-IL}}</ref> Vgames deemed the series "the most daring attempt to create computer games for Israeli audiences only".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080615035703/http://www.vgames.co.il/news_article.aspx?NewsID=14297|title=Special for Independence Day: Free Piposh!|last=Beirav|first=Yuval|date=June 15, 2008|website=Vgames|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=May 26, 2018}}</ref> When news of a fan-made Piposh 2.5 was brought to Nana 10, the site made an emotional appeal to its readers, hoping to attract anyone who could "help this promising project take shape", while hoping it would be the first of many.<ref name=":10" /> Meanwhile, 2all.co.il wished the developers success.<ref name=":13" />
Noting a recent campaign to name a road in Israel "Lara Croft street", Nana 10 hoped that soon there would be a "Piposh street" to honour the series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.10.tv/online/40550|title=On Lara Croft Street you take a right ...|last=David|first=Noa|date=August 3, 2009|website=Nana 10|language=he|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 27, 2018}}</ref> The paper believed Piposh to the possibly the most successful and profitable Israeli computer gaming project, deeming Guillotine a champion of the local industry.<ref name=":12" /> Makorrishon deemed Guillotine a "stubborn pioneer" due to persisting with making a game in Israel, though noted that despite their bravery, the company did close down a mere 6 years later.<ref name=":14" /> Looking back at the games in 2008, Ronen was impressed at how the humour held up, and noted ultimately that Piposh is "not a game of technology, but of people, behavior and relationships".<ref name=":0" />
