revision.text:
The term transformation (also "transition" or "system change") in the field of [[mediated cross-border communication]] refers to a media system's change from for instance [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] or [[Communism|communist]] structures to a new media system with different [[structure]]s and control mechanisms.<ref name="Hadamik">Hadamik (2004), p. 9.</ref>
Compared to the studies of media systems, transformation research is focused on the [[collective]] and [[individual]] actors who "demand, support, and manage change".<ref>Kleinsteuber (2010), p. 26.</ref> They can be found in [[government]]s, [[Political party|parties]], [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]], civil society organizations or [[Advocacy group|interest groups]]. To the largest extent, transformation research addresses change from [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] to [[Democracy|democratic]] media systems. Since transformation processes in media systems are always linked to the political and [[socioeconomic development]], transformation research is not solely focused on the transformation of the media systems, but also on sectors like [[politics]], [[economy]], [[society]], or [[culture]].<ref name="Hadamik" />
Transformation research is a comparative approach, since processes in different stages of the [[Political system|political]] or media system are compared. The approach is highly complex, because it combines comparison with the dimension of space and time, for instance by analyzing similar change processes of media systems in different world regions and times in history. This causes problems, because the changing systems can exhibit considerable differences between one another. Although there are differences between them, transformation processes often occur at the same time and significant similarities between the resulting patterns can be observed.<ref>Kleinsteuber (2010), p. 23-26.</ref>
== Interrelation between transformation processes of political and media systems ==
The transformation research on media systems has its origin in transformation studies of [[political science]]s. Fragments of [[political science]] theories were applied in comparative [[media studies]],<ref>Kleinsteuber (2010), p. 23.</ref> since transformation processes of media systems are strongly connected to the transformation of [[political system]]s.<ref>Voltmer (2008), p. 29.</ref> Katharina Hadamik (2003) describes this connection as "political-medial transformation-parallelism". She stresses that the media system in a [[State (polity)|state]] cannot take any path of transformation. It is connected to the transformation of the [[political system]]. For instance, [[State (polity)|states]] which develop democratic structures and [[constitution]]al conditions in their [[political system]] also build out free or relatively free media systems. In contrast, media systems in [[State (polity)|states]] with weaker or even no transformation of the [[political system]] have much higher barriers of development to overcome.<ref>Hadamik (2004), p. 54-56.</ref> So, "it is the political system that ultimately has the power to make binding decisions and thus shapes the basic structure and functioning of the media system".<ref name="Voltmer">Voltmer (2012), p. 240.</ref> This strong connection between [[political system|political]] and media system can be emphasized by watching the process of transformation from an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] to a [[Democracy|democratic]] [[political system|system]] in both [[politic]]s and [[media (communication)|media]].
The transformation from an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] to a [[Democracy|democratic]] [[political system]] has three phases:<ref>Merkel (1999), p. 119-169.</ref>
Phase 1: end of the old [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] [[regime]]
Phase 2: transformation and [[institutionalisation]] of [[democracy]]
Phase 3: [[democratic consolidation|consolidation of democracy]] through a new system
The process of transformation from an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] to a [[Democracy|democratic]] media system also has three phases, similar to the phases of transformation in [[political system]]s:<ref>Hadamik (2004), p. 57-58.</ref>
Phase 1: breakthrough in the media sector
Phase 2: fixation of the changes in the [[Media (communication)|media]] sector
Phase 3: development of a stable media system
== Types of transformation processes==
In comparative media system research, scholars have identified three processes of change in media systems: homogenization, heterogenization, and hybridization.
=== Homogenization towards one model of media systems ===
In the field of comparative media system research, homogenization is defined as the convergence of many media systems towards one specific model, caused by changes in [[Political structure|political]] and [[economy|economic]] structures, commercialization, and [[technological change|changes in technology]]. [[culture|Cultural]] differences between the countries are said to become less important, since a few international [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerates]] dominate the global [[media (communication)|media]] industry. In 2004, the authors Hallin and Mancini attested a convergence of European media systems towards the [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics#The three models of media and politics|Liberal Media System]] prevalent in North America, the United Kingdom and Ireland. Relating to the convergence of media systems, four constitutive factors can be identified:<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004a), p. 25-41.</ref><ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 251-254, 294-295.</ref><ref>Boczkowski, Mitchelstein & Walter (2011), p. 379.</ref>
* Americanization: The changing [[organizational structure]]s and behaviors within the [[Media (communication)|media]] are heading towards patterns first established in the United States. Moreover, the US American model of politically neutral and professional [[journalism]] is becoming more and more influential for other media systems. The journalistic education of the United States has said to have been a strong influence on journalism cultures worldwide.<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004a), p. 25-28.</ref><ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 254-259.</ref><ref>Hardy (2008), p. 119-122.</ref> * Technological change: New [[technology|technologies]] can lead to adaptations by individuals and social [[institution]]s, for instance assuming new communication procedures associated with the new [[technology]]. These effects often produce common practices across different [[social environment|social contexts]]. The development of professional [[journalism]] is also connected to [[technological change]].<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 259-261.</ref><ref>Hardy (2008), p. 78.</ref> * [[Secularization]]: The term [[secularization]] describes "the separation of citizens from attachments of religious and ideological 'faiths,' and the decline of institutions based on these faiths".<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 263.</ref> This separation results in a decline of political parties, since they are connected to [[ideology|ideologies]] and particular social milieus. Hence, [[secularization]] leads media systems towards the [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics#The three models of media and politics|Liberal Model]].<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004a), p. 28-32, 34-38.</ref><ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 263-267.</ref> * Commercialization: Commercialization can be seen as the most important force of homogenization. It has changed the print [[media (communication)|media]] as well as the electronic [[media (communication)|media]]. The transition of European broadcasting systems, from predominantly public service systems in the 1970s to a system with commercial domination today, gave the strongest impetus for homogenization. Thus, commercialization decreases the ties of media system and [[political system]].<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004a), p. 38-40.</ref><ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 273-282.</ref>
Although a tendency of homogenization towards the [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics#The three models of media and politics|Liberal Model]] can be attested, there still are important differences between the systems. First of all, the variations between the [[political system]]s of each country seem to persist in the future. Furthermore, the [[party system|party]] and [[voting system|electoral systems]] between the countries remain different. Moreover, the [[List of country legal systems|legal systems]] of the countries are still distinct. Also, even though there is a trend towards neutral journalism, [[political parallelism]] in the national press of [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics#The three models of media and politics|Democratic Corporatist]] countries still persists and will probably remain in the immediate future. Thus, a complete converge of the media systems seems unlikely.<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 282-287, 301.</ref><ref>Boczkowski, Mitchelstein & Walter (2011), p. 380.</ref><ref>Hardy (2008), p. 121.</ref>
There are also limits and countertendencies against homogenization. There is evidence of countertendencies relating to the reduction of [[Polarization (politics)|political polarization]] and [[ideology|ideological]] differences between parties. In some countries, new extremist parties on the far right of the political spectrum arose, motivated through issues of [[immigration]], [[multiculturalism]] and integration. Moreover, so called [[advocacy journalism]] does not only persist in [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics#The three models of media and politics|Polarized Pluralist]] countries (especially in Italy, Spain and Greece), but new forms of it are also beginning to proliferate in all kinds of media systems.<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 284-285, 301.</ref>
=== Heterogenization of media systems ===
Some scholars argue against the [[theory]] of homogenization of media systems that due to national [[political culture]]s and [[institution]]s, a process of heterogenization rather than homogenization, has to be stated.<ref>Boczkowski, Mitchelstein & Walter (2011), p. 377.</ref> The countertendencies of homogenization (for instance new right extremist parties, new forms of [[advocacy journalism]], divergence processes in the styles of election coverage between the United States and Great Britain) lead to heterogenization of the media systems.<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 284-285.</ref> However, the divergence of media systems is confronted by a much more fundamental convergence between them.<ref>Boczkowski, Mitchelstein & Walter (2011), p. 389.</ref> Hallin & Mancini also argue that the results of their analysis do not support the thesis of heterogenization of media systems.<ref>Hallin & Mancini (2004b), p. 86.</ref>
=== Hybridization of media systems ===
Hybrid media systems are defined as a blend of already existing practices and new practices from a new or foreign media system. Foreign models are adapted to the particular [[history|historical]], geographical, [[social]], and [[culture|cultural]] characteristics of the domestic media system.<ref name="Voltmer" /><ref>de Albuquerque (2012), p. 89.</ref><ref>Hadamik (2004), p. 55.</ref><ref>Coman (2000), p. 54.</ref> Rather than a temporary state of transformation, hybrid media systems are considered an [[:wikt:equilibrium|equilibrium]] between two types of practices. Thus, hybrid media systems are mostly located between [[authoritarianism|authoritarian]] and [[democracy|democratic]] [[political system]]s. Although they may have introduced competitive elections, they may not strengthen further [[democracy|democratic]] [[institution]]s beyond the basic requirements. Therefore, the degree to which hybrid systems adopt [[democracy|democratic]] practices can vary from state to state. Hybrid systems build out distinct patterns of politic-media relations with significant differences to Western media systems,<ref>Voltmer (2012), p. 231-245.</ref><ref>Roudakova (2012), p. 247.</ref> for instance the Brazilian media system, which was influenced by the American [[journalism]] model. However, the American [[journalism]] system was not adopted one-to-one, since there "was no solid [[market economy]], [[individualistic culture]], or [[political culture]] that valued the freedom of press".<ref>de Albuquerque (2012), p. 82.</ref> Another example is the media system of Poland, which detached itself from its [[communism|communist]] ties in the 1990s and converged towards Western media systems, but still has its Polish specifics, such as the use of [[Public broadcasting|public-service broadcasting]] as a political instrument.<ref>Hadamik (2004), p. 324.</ref>
According to the three phases from an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] to a [[democracy|democratic]] media system, the old [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] system ends by the [[institutionalisation]] of [[democracy|democratic]] elements (phase 1 and 2). In the third phase, the new hybrid system consolidates [[democracy|democratic]] elements, but some elements of the [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] system still exist. Thus, it is difficult to state when the third phase is completed.
In Hallin & Mancini's ''Comparing media systems beyond the western world'' (2012), which gives an overview of criticism about their [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics|framework of 2004]] and furthermore extends and revises it, Katrin Voltmer states that, instead of media system homogenization towards the [[Comparing Media Systems: Three Models of Media and Politics#The three models of media and politics|Liberal Model]] of Hallin & Mancini's framework, transformation processes rather move towards hybrid media systems, since [[media (communication)|media]] markets become more international, but have to adapt to local situations. Thus, the theory of hybridization in media systems is rather an adaption than a counterpart to the theory of convergence.<ref>Voltmer (2012), p. 231.</ref>
== Outlook == A consistent transformation [[theory]] valid for all transformation processes and countries, does not yet exist, since it is difficult to cover the variety and complexity of all the processes. Some researchers are of the opinion that it is impossible to find a consistent theory of transformation processes, because of the historical, political and social particularities of each country and their different types of transformation processes.<ref>Hadamik (2004), p. 23.</ref> Furthermore, the debate about convergence, divergence, or hybridization of media systems is still ongoing.<ref>Boczkowski, Mitchelstein & Walter (2011), p. 377, 385-391.</ref>

(2012). Comparing Processes: Media, "Transitions", and Historical Change. In D. C. Hallin & P.
